commands.name: aliases
commands.description: Generates Pantheon Drush aliases for sites on which the currently logged-in user is on the team.
usage: aliases Saves Pantheon Drush aliases for sites on which the currently logged-in user is on the team to ~/.drush/pantheon.aliases.drushrc.php.
aliases --print Displays Pantheon Drush 8 aliases for sites on which the currently logged-in user is on the team.
aliases --location=<full_path> Saves Pantheon Drush 8 aliases for sites on which the currently logged-in user is on the team to <full_path>.
commands.help: Generates Pantheon Drush aliases for sites on which the currently logged-in user is on the team.

location.description: Path and filename for php aliases.

all.name: --all
all.description: Include all sites available, including team memberships.

only.name: --only
only.description: Only generate aliases for sites in the specified comma-separated list. This option is only recommended for use in CI scripts.

type.name: --type
type.description: Type of aliases to create: 'php', 'yml' or 'all'.

target.description: Base name to use to generate path to alias files.

commands.name: completion
commands.description: Dump the shell completion script
commands.help:
The <info>completion</> command dumps the shell completion script required
to use shell autocompletion (currently only bash completion is supported).

<comment>Static installation
-------------------</>

Dump the script to a global completion file and restart your shell:

    <info>/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus//terminus.phar completion bash | sudo tee /etc/bash_completion.d/terminus.phar</>

Or dump the script to a local file and source it:

    <info>/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus//terminus.phar completion bash > completion.sh</>

    <comment># source the file whenever you use the project</>
    <info>source completion.sh</>

    <comment># or add this line at the end of your "~/.bashrc" file:</>
    <info>source /path/to/completion.sh</>

<comment>Dynamic installation
--------------------</>

Add this add the end of your shell configuration file (e.g. <info>"~/.bashrc"</>):

    <info>eval "$(/private/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus/terminus.phar completion bash)"</>

commands.name: help
commands.description: Display help for a command
commands.help:
The <info>help</info> command displays help for a given command:

  <info>/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus//terminus.phar help list</info>

You can also output the help in other formats by using the <comment>--format</comment> option:

  <info>/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus//terminus.phar help --format=xml list</info>

To display the list of available commands, please use the <info>list</info> command.

commands.name: list
commands.description: List commands
commands.help:
The <info>list</info> command lists all commands:

  <info>/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus//terminus.phar list</info>

You can also display the commands for a specific namespace:

  <info>/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus//terminus.phar list test</info>

You can also output the information in other formats by using the <comment>--format</comment> option:

  <info>/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus//terminus.phar list --format=xml</info>

It's also possible to get raw list of commands (useful for embedding command runner):

  <info>/var/folders/0_/658_c7z15551g451_s0628zw0000gn/T/update-tool/terminus//terminus.phar list --raw</info>

commands.help: Enables automatic daily backups that are retained for one week and weekly backups retained for one month.

day.description: Day of the week to make the month-long backup in any format recognized by PHP strtotime

keep-for.description: Retention period, in days, to retain the weekly backup. The default is 32 days.

commands.name: build:project:create
commands.description: Create a new project from the requested source GitHub project. Does the following operations: - Creates a git repository forked from the source project. - Creates a Pantheon site to run the tests on. - Sets up CI to test the repository. In order to use this command, it is also necessary to provide a set of secrets that are used to create the necessary projects, and that are subsequentially cached in Circle CI for use during the test run. Currently, these secrets should be provided via environment variables; this keeps them out of the command history and other places they may be inadvertantly observed.
commands.help:
GitHub configuration:
export GITHUB_TOKEN=github_personal_access_token

BitBucket configuration:
export BITBUCKET_USER=bitbucket_username
export BITBUCKET_PASS=bitbucket_account_or_app_password

CircleCI configuration:
export CIRCLE_TOKEN=circle_personal_api_token

GitLab/GitLabCI configuration:
export GITLAB_TOKEN=gitlab_personal_access_token

Composer authentication details (if necessary):
export TERMINUS_BUILD_TOOLS_COMPOSER_AUTH=json_encoded_string

Secrets that are not exported will be prompted.

source.name: source
source.description: Packagist org/name of source template project to fork or path to an existing project on the local filesystem. Paths must either start with ./ or be an absolute path.

target.description: Simple name of project to create.

org.description: Organization for the new project (defaults to authenticated user)

pantheon-site.description: Name of Pantheon site to create (defaults to 'target' argument)

label.name: --label
label.description: The friendly name to use for the Pantheon site (defaults to the name of the Git site).

email.name: --email
email.description: email address to place in ssh-key

test-site-name.description: The name to use when installing the test site.

admin-password.description: The password to use for the CMS admin when installing the test site.

admin-email.description: The email address to use for the CMS admin.

admin-username.description: The username to use for the CMS admin.

stability.description: Minimum allowed stability for template project.

env.description: Add extra environment variables to the CI environment. For example, --env='key=value' --env='another=v2'.

preserve-local-repository.description: If given, use the repository in the existing source directory. Otherwise, use composer create-project to create a new local copy of the source project.

keep.name: --keep
keep.description: If given, clone a local copy of the project.

use-ssh.description: Use SSH instead of HTTPS to create the provider repository.

ci.name: --ci
ci.description: Specify a CI provider. Options are circleci, gitlab-pipelines, bitbucket-pipelines and githubactions. If not provided, CI will be assigned based on git provider choice (Note that the default CI for Github is CircleCI).

git.description: Specify a git provider. Options are github (default), gitlab, and bitbucket.

visibility.name: --visibility
visibility.description: The desired visibility of the provider repository. Options are public, internal, and private.

region.name: --region
region.description: Specify a data residency region. See https://pantheon.io/docs/regions#available-regions for the current region options.

template-repository.description: Composer repository if package is hosted on a private registry or url to git.

ci-template.description: Git repo that contains the CI scripts that will be copied if there is no ci in the source project.

clu-cron-pattern.name: --clu-cron-pattern
clu-cron-pattern.description: Specify a cron pattern to override the given CI provider's clu task schedule, if applicable. For example, '0 0 * * 1' to run once a week at midnight on monday.

commands.name: env:clone-content
commands.description: Clones database/files from one environment to another environment.
usage: env:clone-content <site>.<env> <target_env> Clones database and files from <site>'s <env> environment to <target_env> environment.
env:clone-content <site>.<env> <target_env> --cc Clones from <site>'s <env> environment to <target_env> environment and clears the database.
env:clone-content <site>.<env> <target_env> --db-only Clones only the database from <site>'s <env> environment to <target_env> environment.
env:clone-content <site>.<env> <target_env> --files-only Clones only files from <site>'s <env> environment to <target_env> environment.
env:clone-content <site>.<env> <target_env> --updatedb Clones from <site>'s <env> environment to <target_env> environment and updates the Drupal database (if applicable).
commands.help: Clones database/files from one environment to another environment.

commands.name: env:deploy
commands.description: Deploys code to the Test or Live environment. Notes: - Deploying the Test environment will deploy code from the Dev environment. - Deploying the Live environment will deploy code from the Test environment.
usage: env:deploy <site>.test Deploy code from <site>'s Dev environment to the Test environment.
env:deploy <site>.live Deploy code from <site>'s Test environment to the Live environment.
env:deploy <site>.test --sync-content Deploy code from <site>'s Dev environment to the Test environment and clone content from the Live environment to the Test environment.
env:deploy <site>.live --updatedb Deploy code from <site>'s Test environment to the Live environment and run Drupal's update.php.
env:deploy <site>.live --note=<message> Deploy code from <site>'s Test environment to the Live environment with the deploy log message <message>.
commands.help: Deploys code to the Test or Live environment. Notes: - Deploying the Test environment will deploy code from the Dev environment. - Deploying the Live environment will deploy code from the Test environment.

accept-upstream.description: Attempt to automatically resolve conflicts in favor of the upstream

help.name: --help
help.description: Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the <info>list</info> command

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question

simulate.name: --simulate
simulate.description: Run in simulated mode (show what would have happened).

progress-delay.name: --progress-delay
progress-delay.description: Number of seconds before progress bar is displayed in long-running task collections. Default: 2s.

commands.name: upstream:updates:list
commands.description: Displays a cached list of new code commits available from the upstream for a site development environment. Note: To refresh the cache you will need to run site:upstream:clear-cache before running this command.
usage: upstream:updates:list <site>.<env> Displays a list of new code commits available from the upstream for <site>'s <env> environment.
commands.help: Displays a cached list of new code commits available from the upstream for a site development environment. Note: To refresh the cache you will need to run site:upstream:clear-cache before running this command.

format.name: --format
format.description: Format the result data. Available formats: csv,json,list,null,php,print-r,sections,string,table,tsv,var_export,xml,yaml

fields.name: --fields
fields.description: Available fields: Commit ID (hash), Timestamp (datetime), Message (message), Author (author)

field.name: --field
field.description: Select just one field, and force format to *string*.

commands.name: upstream:updates:status
commands.description: Displays a whether there are updates available from the upstream for a site environment.
usage: upstream:updates:status <site>.<env> Displays either "outdated" if <site>'s <env> environment has upstream updates or "current" if not.
commands.help: Displays a whether there are updates available from the upstream for a site environment.

commands.name: workflow:info:logs
commands.description: Displays the details of a workflow including Quicksilver operation logs.
usage: workflow:info:logs <site> --id=<workflow> Displays the details of <site>'s workflow <workflow>.
workflow:info:logs <site> Displays the details of <site>'s most recently created workflow.
